Here’s another really odd thing I’ve noticed about vision. (If you could explain it, I’d be very happy)
If you’re watching TV or looking at something dynamic and in your peripheral vision, there is a reflection of what you’re watching. When the shot changes or something is altered in what you’re watching, there is a noticeable lag between the main source you’re watching and when the reflection of it changes in your peripheral vision.

For example, watch TV and set your (smart) phone down next to you with the screen locked so that the glass surface basically becomes a mirror and you can see the tv in the reflection of it. If you focus on the TV but can see your phone in your peripheral vision, when the shot changes, you’ll see the shot change on the tv then, just slightly after the tv, the shot changes in the reflection of your phone.

My assumption is that your brain is more quickly processing what’s in the main center of your field of view and then processes the stuff out of the corner of your eye later????

Also have noticed many times that my brain has its own noise canceling if it comes to clocks: I don’t hear the clock in my room ticking unless I concentrate myself on that sound and then I can’t unhear it for the next minutes…

I actually notice the saccades with my ceiling fan. I just move my eyes back and forth between the walls. It makes the ceiling fan look like it is staying still for just a bit longer than reality, making it look like it is moving slower than when you look straight at it.
